metadata.title: The 'cool Camino': Why hikers are heading north

content.text: The 'cool Camino': Why hikers are heing north7 hours agoShareSaveLizzie EnfieldShareSaveAlamy(Credit: Alamy)Every summer, Spain's iconic Camino bakes under extreme heat, but Norway's St Olav Ways offer pilgrims a quieter, cooler path to redemption.Picking my way across a hummocky field, I shiver as I reach the edge of one of Norway's largest Viking-age graveyards. Vang, on the outskirts of Oppdal, is an undulating patchwork of nearly 900 turf-covered mounds, most dating from between 750 and 1050 CE. It's not just the proximity to the deceased that gives me goosebumps but the temperature: a cool 13C in late August. Chilly for summer sightseeing, but perfect for hiking.I am walking the Gudbrandsdalen path, one of nine St Olav Ways that thre in from Finland, Sweden and across Norway, all converging on Trondheim where Norway's most famous medieval king, St Olav, is buried.The path is quiet. Moss softens the stones along the route. Shafts of light pierce spruce forest; rivers run cold and clear enough to drink from them. This is pilgrimage, Nordic style. And in an era of climate extremes, it offers welcome respite from the heat of Europe's iconic pilgrim trails.In August this year, parts of Spain's legendary Camino de Santiago sweltered at 45C. A 16-day heatwave fuelled wildfires, forcing authorities to close more than 50km of the route between Astorga and Ponferra. Pilgrims were diverted or gave up; one walker died of heatstroke on a section of the Portuguese Coastal Way. Spanish media warned that the Camino was becoming not only overcrowded, but dangerous.By contrast, the St Olav Ways promise what some now call a "coolcation": milder air, long daylight, and space to walk without a throng of pilgrims.Lizzie EnfieldSt Olav Ways winds through tranquil Norwegian landscapes, offering a slower-paced pilgrimage route along forests and fjords (Credit: Lizzie Enfield)"The paths combine countryside, culture, religion and encounters with locals. But what differs in Norway are the longer stretches of nature, mountains and pristine environment," says Mattias Jansson of the National Pilgrim Centre in Trondheim. "Anecdotally we hear many pilgrims say that they visit Norway due to the cooler temperatures. This matters when you will hike for many hours a day."What differs in Norway are the longer stretches of nature, mountains and pristine environment - Mattias JanssonBack in the Middle Ages, the paths to Europe's northernmost cathedral were among the four great pilgrim routes, along with Rome, Jerusalem and Santiago. After the Reformation, they fell into disuse. But in the late 1990s, the Norwegian government restored them to attract latter-day pilgrims.Today the trails are well marked with the distinctive red cross of St Olav superimposed over Norway's grey cultural heritage logo. These are painted on marker posts, rocks and wooden pendants hung from trees.The Gudbrandsdalen path remains the most popular, running 643km from Oslo to Trondheim through farmland, forests, fjords and the open expanses of the Dovre mountains. The full route takes about a month, but shorter sections are easily walked. I opted for the final stretch between Oppdal and Trondheim, covering around 150km over a week. Heing north, the foothills of the Dovre rose to one side, fertile farmland where sheep and reindeer grazed stretched on the other. Tarred timber farm buildings, sun-darkened to a mottled sheen, lined the way.Getty ImagesPilgrims pass landmarks like Ringebu Stave Church, a medieval wooden church with a striking red spire (Credit: Getty Images)The route is not only cooler than the Camino, but quieter. Last year almost half a million pilgrims received the Compostela certificate for walking 100km or more in Spain. In Norway the numbers are tiny by comparison, though growing. In 2015, around 700 hiked the last 100km to Trondheim; last year that figure rose to almost 1,000."Each summer we have more than 40 nationalities arriving on the pilgrim path to Nidaros Cathedral," says Jansson. "The majority are from Germany, the Netherlands, UK and America." Plan your trip:When to go: June-September (long daylight, mild weather, though rain is likely).Where to walk: The Gudbrandsdalen path runs 643km from Oslo to Trondheim (≈ one month). Many walk shorter sections, such as Oppdal–Trondheim (150 km; 7-10 days).Where to stay: Hotels, guesthouses, converted barns, wild camping under allemannsretten. Book in vance for July/August.What to take: Waterproofs, layered clothing, broken-in boots, food supplies for remote stretches.More info: pilegrimsleden.noMany hikers are actively looking north."Of the people we talk to and meet, we hear that they are looking for alternatives to the Camino – both because of the amount of pilgrims in Spain, but also because of the extreme weather conditions," says Sacha Kraan, co-owner of Nordic Pilgrim, a Dutch-based operator specialising in St Olav routes. "Often they hear about the Nordic trails when walking the Camino. They want to hike mostly alone through rugged landscapes with a rich history – and that is what you get along the Nordic trails."That history is visible in stave churches such as Ringebu, 180km north of Oslo. Once Norway h more than 1,000; now only 28 of these medieval wooden buildings survive. Elsewhere the path passes the ruined cathedral at Hamar, Bronze Age settlements, and rocks said to bear Olav's horse's hoofprint. Information boxes along the route open to reveal local stories: a clearing once used as a football pitch, another hacked out by a sorcerer.Like the Camino, walkers here come for many reasons. In the mountains I met four Germans who h abandoned plans to hike in Romania after hearing of bears. Climbing up what locals wryly call "Norwegian flat", I caught up with 73-year-old Synnøve Skåksrud, a retired psychiatrist who h alrey walked the Via Romea Germanica from northern Germany to Rome.Getty ImagesStone markers along the route show the distance to Nidaros Cathedral, the pilgrimage's endpoint in Trondheim (Credit: Getty Images)"Walking in Norway, where there are large variations in nature and weather, makes it more demanding than walking through [Southern] Europe," she said. "The biggest challenge was rainy weather and slippery rocks, differences in altitude and rough terrain. [Elsewhere] in Europe, pilgrims meet in cafes and pubs; churches are open. In Norway, you must carry your food, and many churches are locked. Yet there are compensations: silence, birdsong, rain, fresh air and a sense of being part of the landscape rather than moving through it."More like this:• A new love for medieval-style travel• What Santiago's many 'Camino' pilgrims often miss• The controversial sweet that fuels NorwegiansAccommodation is as varied as the scenery. In Oppdal the Tourist Hotel provides a comfortable base with hearty breakfasts. A few days further on, the elegant Orkla Gjestebolig – once the guest house of a copper mine owner – offers art-filled rooms near the Orkla Industrial Museum. Mostly, though, pilgrim beds are humbler: converted barns with bunks where animals once slept and simple farmhouses with painted wooden furniture."The Nordic trails are not as developed as the Camino: there are fewer accommodations, and the infrastructure is still in its infancy," Kraan mits. "There are no places to sleep every few kilometres and the standard varies – from hotel to B&B to a simple cabin in someone's backyard. If you don't pre-book in the main season, you might find yourself without a bed. But you can always set up your tent in the wild, thanks to allemannsretten, the Nordic 'everyman's right'."Three days in, I reached the Orkla, a crystal-clear river famed for salmon. Fish features heavily on menus: salmon, mussels and bakt klippfisk (baked salt cod), alongside pilgrim staples such as lamb stew. Most distinctive of all is rømmegrøt, a sour-cream porridge with butter, flour and salt — heavy but moreish, perfect fuel for long days. When the path dips into forest, the feast continues: blueberries and cranberries by the handful, or with luck, rare and aptly named cloudberries.Getty ImagesNidaros Cathedral, built on the burial site of St Olav, has been a pilgrimage destination for nearly a millennium (Credit: Getty Images)The final days bring the landscape down from high forest to fields of corn and barley. Joggers and roller skaters replace sheep and clapboard houses with fish-scale tiles signal that Trondheim is close. Then, suddenly, the spire of Nidaros Cathedral pierces the skyline – a brooding masterpiece of soapstone with intricate carvings and a great rose window glowing crimson in the late afternoon sun.It is an arrival very different from Santiago. There are no queues in the beating sun, no saintly relics to see. Inste, a small, almost unnoticed altar near the wall marks Olav's resting place, scattered with rose petals and pilgrim stones.Spain's Camino remains iconic, but the heat brought by climate change has me it increasingly challenging. In Norway, on paths once trodden by Vikings and saints, it is still possible to walk with climate, culture and conscience: across windswept landscapes, through tritional Nordic towns and beneath endless skies.-- If you liked this story, sign up for The Essential List newsletter – a handpicked selection of features, videos and can't-miss news, delivered to your inbox twice a week. For more Travel stories from the BBC, follow us on Facebook and Instagram.HikingNature & OutdoorsFeatures

class="sc-c387a658-0 iltMZV"><div class="sc-5340b511-1 fscfXX" data-testid="hero-image"><img aria-label="image unavailable" class="sc-5340b511-0 hagXkB hide-when-no-script" src="https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20250919-090805-05e5ba0164-web-2.30.1-2/grey-placeholder.png"/><img alt="Alamy Person in distance hiking on path through countryside on St Olavs Way, Norway (Credit: Lizzie Enfield)" class="sc-5340b511-0 bGQwLJ" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 1280px) 50vw, (min-width: 1008px) 66vw, 96vw" src="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0m58jx8.jpg.webp" srcset="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/160xn/p0m58jx8.jpg.webp 160w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/240xn/p0m58jx8.jpg.webp 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/320xn/p0m58jx8.jpg.webp 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0m58jx8.jpg.webp 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/640xn/p0m58jx8.jpg.webp 640w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1920xn/p0m58jx8.jpg.webp 1920w"/><span class="sc-5340b511-2 lha-dta">Alamy</span></div></div><div class="sc-c387a658-0 iFXyJX"><figcaption class="sc-536eff7b-0 jFVvLh">(Credit: Alamy)</figcaption></div></figure></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 bwCwRh" data-component="layout-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 iFXyJX"><div class="sc-85f9acf9-0 kySSTS"><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ"><b class="sc-d16436d-0 kPzeuB" id="every-summer,-spain's-iconic-camino-bakes-under-extreme-heat,-but-norway's-st-olav-ways-offer-pilgrims-a-quieter,-cooler-path-to-redemption.">Every summer, Spain's iconic Camino bakes under extreme heat, but Norway's St Olav Ways offer pilgrims a quieter, cooler path to redemption.</b></p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">Picking my way across a hummocky field, I shiver as I reach the edge of one of Norway's largest <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.visitnorway.com/places-to-go/trondelag/listings-trondelag/the-viking-burial-site-at-vang/279926/" target="_blank">Viking-age graveyards</a>. Vang, on the outskirts of Oppdal, is an undulating patchwork of nearly 900 turf-covered mounds, most dating from between 750 and 1050 CE. It's not just the proximity to the deceased that gives me goosebumps but the temperature: a cool 13C in late August. Chilly for summer sightseeing, but perfect for hiking.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">I am walking the <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.pilegrimsleden.no/en/trails/gudbrandsdalsleden" target="_blank">Gudbrandsdalen path</a>, one of nine <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.coe.int/en/web/cultural-routes/the-route-of-saint-olav-ways" target="_blank">St Olav Ways</a> that thread in from Finland, Sweden and across Norway, all converging on Trondheim where Norway's most famous medieval king, St Olav, is buried.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">The path is quiet. Moss softens the stones along the route. Shafts of light pierce spruce forest; rivers run cold and clear enough to drink from them. This is pilgrimage, Nordic style. And in an era of climate extremes, it offers welcome respite from the heat of Europe's iconic pilgrim trails.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">In August this year, parts of Spain's legendary Camino de Santiago sweltered at 45C. A 16-day heatwave fuelled wildfires, forcing authorities to close more than 50km of the route between Astorga and Ponferrada. Pilgrims were diverted or gave up; one walker <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/vigo/2025/05/30/fallece-peregrino-aleman-55-anos-arcadetrassufrir-infarto-golpe-calor/00031748618491680739418.htm" target="_blank">died of heatstroke</a> on a section of the <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.bbc.com/travel/article/20240605-the-portuguese-pilgrimage-you-should-do-in-2024" target="_self">Portuguese Coastal Way</a>. Spanish media <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://ctif.org/news/spain-wildfires-close-parts-famous-pilgrimage-trail-firefighter-died-fire-engine-crash" target="_blank">warned</a> that the Camino was becoming not only overcrowded, but dangerous.</p></div></div><div class="sc-c387a658-0 iRUDzL"><div class="sc-1b734f04-0 csvmva" data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit"><div class="dotcom-ad" data-testid="dotcom-sid_1" id="dotcom-sid_1"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 emRbmv" data-component="advertisement-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 gmBvdA"><div class="sc-1b734f04-1 hBNPuc" data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit"><div class="dotcom-ad" data-testid="dotcom-mid_1" id="dotcom-mid_1"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 bwCwRh" data-component="layout-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 iFXyJX"><div class="sc-85f9acf9-0 kySSTS"><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">By contrast, the St Olav Ways promise what some now call a "coolcation": milder air, long daylight, and space to walk without a throng of pilgrims.</p><figure class="sc-bc40c3a0-0 cEiEXq"><div class="sc-5340b511-1 iLpiHp" data-testid="image"><img aria-label="image unavailable" class="sc-5340b511-0 hagXkB hide-when-no-script" src="https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20250919-090805-05e5ba0164-web-2.30.1-2/grey-placeholder.png"/><img alt="Lizzie Enfield St Olav Ways winds through tranquil Norwegian landscapes, offering a slower-paced pilgrimage route along forests and fjords (Credit: Lizzie Enfield)" class="sc-5340b511-0 bGQwLJ" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 1280px) 50vw, (min-width: 1008px) 66vw, 96vw" src="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0m4vxn5.jpg.webp" srcset="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/160xn/p0m4vxn5.jpg.webp 160w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/240xn/p0m4vxn5.jpg.webp 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/320xn/p0m4vxn5.jpg.webp 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0m4vxn5.jpg.webp 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/640xn/p0m4vxn5.jpg.webp 640w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/800xn/p0m4vxn5.jpg.webp 800w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1024xn/p0m4vxn5.jpg.webp 1024w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1376xn/p0m4vxn5.jpg.webp 1376w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1920xn/p0m4vxn5.jpg.webp 1920w"/><span class="sc-5340b511-2 lha-dta">Lizzie Enfield</span></div><figcaption class="sc-536eff7b-0 jFVvLh">St Olav Ways winds through tranquil Norwegian landscapes, offering a slower-paced pilgrimage route along forests and fjords (Credit: Lizzie Enfield)</figcaption></figure><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">"The paths combine countryside, culture, religion and encounters with locals. But what differs in Norway are the longer stretches of nature, mountains and pristine environment," says Mattias Jansson of the National Pilgrim Centre in Trondheim. "Anecdotally we hear many pilgrims say that they visit Norway due to the cooler temperatures. This matters when you will hike for many hours a day."</p><div class="sc-2b8ea91d-0 bgzaEJ"><div class="sc-2b8ea91d-1 bnPcFP"><svg category="personalisation" class="sc-9c8c5e05-0 iXimKF" height="1em" icon="quote" viewbox="0 0 32 32" width="1em"><path d="M9.83967 17.2131C9.205 17.2131 8.62967 17.3124 8.07567 17.5058C8.63767 13.3384 10.9143 10.0091 14.7517 6.88708H10.0903C6.281 10.2704 4.00033 14.6318 4.00033 20.0451C4.00033 24.4311 6.35567 26.9371 9.78967 26.9371C13.0223 26.9371 14.9023 24.5564 14.9023 21.9751C14.9023 19.2184 12.7217 17.2131 9.83967 17.2131Z"></path><path d="M22.2957 17.2131C21.6611 17.2131 21.0864 17.3124 20.5317 17.5058C21.0931 13.3384 23.3704 10.0091 27.2077 6.88708H22.5464C18.7371 10.2704 16.4811 14.6318 16.4811 20.0451C16.4811 24.4311 18.8117 26.9371 22.2457 26.9371C25.4784 26.9371 27.3584 24.5564 27.3584 21.9751C27.3584 19.2184 25.1777 17.2131 22.2957 17.2131Z"></path></svg></div><span class="sc-2b8ea91d-2 kniMbd">What differs in Norway are the longer stretches of nature, mountains and pristine environment - Mattias Jansson</span></div><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">Back in the Middle Ages, the paths to Europe's northernmost cathedral were among the four great pilgrim routes, along with Rome, Jerusalem and Santiago. After the Reformation, they fell into disuse. But in the late 1990s, the Norwegian government restored them to attract latter-day pilgrims.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 emRbmv" data-component="advertisement-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 gmBvdA"><div class="sc-1b734f04-1 hBNPuc" data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit"><div class="dotcom-ad" data-testid="dotcom-mid_2" id="dotcom-mid_2"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 bwCwRh" data-component="layout-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 iFXyJX"><div class="sc-85f9acf9-0 kySSTS"><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">Today the trails are well marked with the distinctive red cross of St Olav superimposed over Norway's grey cultural heritage logo. These are painted on marker posts, rocks and wooden pendants hung from trees.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">The Gudbrandsdalen path remains the most popular, running 643km from Oslo to Trondheim through farmland, forests, fjords and the open expanses of the Dovre mountains. The full route takes about a month, but shorter sections are easily walked. I opted for the final stretch between Oppdal and Trondheim, covering around 150km over a week. Heading north, the foothills of the Dovre rose to one side, fertile farmland where sheep and reindeer grazed stretched on the other. Tarred timber farm buildings, sun-darkened to a mottled sheen, lined the way.</p><figure class="sc-bc40c3a0-0 cEiEXq"><div class="sc-5340b511-1 iLpiHp" data-testid="image"><img aria-label="image unavailable" class="sc-5340b511-0 hagXkB hide-when-no-script" src="https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20250919-090805-05e5ba0164-web-2.30.1-2/grey-placeholder.png"/><img alt="Getty Images Pilgrims pass landmarks like Ringebu Stave Church, a medieval wooden church with a striking red spire (Credit: Getty Images)" class="sc-5340b511-0 bGQwLJ" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 1280px) 50vw, (min-width: 1008px) 66vw, 96vw" src="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0m4vx4w.jpg.webp" srcset="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/160xn/p0m4vx4w.jpg.webp 160w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/240xn/p0m4vx4w.jpg.webp 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/320xn/p0m4vx4w.jpg.webp 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0m4vx4w.jpg.webp 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/640xn/p0m4vx4w.jpg.webp 640w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/800xn/p0m4vx4w.jpg.webp 800w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1024xn/p0m4vx4w.jpg.webp 1024w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1376xn/p0m4vx4w.jpg.webp 1376w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1920xn/p0m4vx4w.jpg.webp 1920w"/><span class="sc-5340b511-2 lha-dta">Getty Images</span></div><figcaption class="sc-536eff7b-0 jFVvLh">Pilgrims pass landmarks like Ringebu Stave Church, a medieval wooden church with a striking red spire (Credit: Getty Images)</figcaption></figure><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">The route is not only cooler than the Camino, but quieter. Last year almost half a million pilgrims received the Compostela certificate for walking 100km or more in Spain. In Norway the numbers are tiny by comparison, though growing. In 2015, around 700 hiked the last 100km to Trondheim; last year that figure rose to almost 1,000.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">"Each summer we have more than 40 nationalities arriving on the pilgrim path to Nidaros Cathedral," says Jansson. "The majority are from Germany, the Netherlands, UK and America."  </p></div></div><div class="sc-c387a658-0 iRUDzL"><div class="sc-1b734f04-0 csvmva" data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit"><div class="dotcom-ad" data-testid="dotcom-sid_2" id="dotcom-sid_2"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 emRbmv" data-component="advertisement-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 gmBvdA"><div class="sc-1b734f04-1 hBNPuc" data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit"><div class="dotcom-ad" data-testid="dotcom-mid_3" id="dotcom-mid_3"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 bwCwRh" data-component="layout-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 iFXyJX"><div class="sc-85f9acf9-0 kySSTS"><section class="sc-2d378821-0 kvTRRg"><div class="sc-2d378821-1 ldBetg"><p class="sc-2d378821-3 ksHcJi">Plan your trip:</p><div class="sc-2d378821-2 lfxgrp"><div class="sc-2d378821-4 gxOvAN"><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ"><b class="sc-d16436d-0 kPzeuB" id="when-to-go:">When to go:</b> June-September (long daylight, mild weather, though rain is likely).</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ"><b class="sc-d16436d-0 kPzeuB" id="where-to-walk:">Where to walk:</b> The Gudbrandsdalen path runs 643km from Oslo to Trondheim (≈ one month). Many walk shorter sections, such as Oppdal–Trondheim (150 km; 7-10 days).</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ"><b class="sc-d16436d-0 kPzeuB" id="where-to-stay:">Where to stay:</b> Hotels, guesthouses, converted barns, wild camping under <i class="sc-d16436d-0 gbdkAi" id="allemannsretten">allemannsretten</i>. Book in advance for July/August.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ"><b class="sc-d16436d-0 kPzeuB" id="what-to-take:">What to take:</b> Waterproofs, layered clothing, broken-in boots, food supplies for remote stretches.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ"><b class="sc-d16436d-0 kPzeuB" id="more-info:">More info:</b> <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://pilegrimsleden.no" target="_blank">pilegrimsleden.no</a></p></div></div></div></section><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">Many hikers are actively looking north.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">"Of the people we talk to and meet, we hear that they are looking for alternatives to the Camino – both because of the amount of pilgrims in Spain, but also because of the extreme weather conditions," says Sacha Kraan, co-owner of <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.nordicpilgrim.com/" target="_blank">Nordic Pilgrim</a>, a Dutch-based operator specialising in St Olav routes. "Often they hear about the Nordic trails when walking the Camino. They want to hike mostly alone through rugged landscapes with a rich history – and that is what you get along the Nordic trails."</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">That history is visible in stave churches such as Ringebu, 180km north of Oslo. Once Norway had more than 1,000; now only 28 of these medieval wooden buildings survive. Elsewhere the path passes the ruined <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.visitnorway.com/listings/hamar-cathedral/2335/" target="_blank">cathedral</a> at Hamar, Bronze Age settlements, and rocks said to bear Olav's horse's hoofprint. Information boxes along the route open to reveal local stories: a clearing once used as a football pitch, another hacked out by a sorcerer.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">Like the Camino, walkers here come for many reasons. In the mountains I met four Germans who had abandoned plans to hike in Romania after hearing of bears. Climbing up what locals wryly call "Norwegian flat", I caught up with 73-year-old Synnøve Skåksrud, a retired psychiatrist who had already walked the <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://viaromeagermanica.it/en/" target="_blank">Via Romea Germanica</a> from northern Germany to Rome.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 emRbmv" data-component="advertisement-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 gmBvdA"><div class="sc-1b734f04-1 hBNPuc" data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit"><div class="dotcom-ad" data-testid="dotcom-mid_4" id="dotcom-mid_4"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 bwCwRh" data-component="layout-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 iFXyJX"><div class="sc-85f9acf9-0 kySSTS"><figure class="sc-bc40c3a0-0 cEiEXq"><div class="sc-5340b511-1 iLpiHp" data-testid="image"><img aria-label="image unavailable" class="sc-5340b511-0 hagXkB hide-when-no-script" src="https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20250919-090805-05e5ba0164-web-2.30.1-2/grey-placeholder.png"/><img alt="Getty Images Stone markers along the route show the distance to Nidaros Cathedral, the pilgrimage's endpoint in Trondheim (Credit: Getty Images)" class="sc-5340b511-0 bGQwLJ" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 1280px) 50vw, (min-width: 1008px) 66vw, 96vw" src="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0m4vwxz.jpg.webp" srcset="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/160xn/p0m4vwxz.jpg.webp 160w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/240xn/p0m4vwxz.jpg.webp 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/320xn/p0m4vwxz.jpg.webp 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0m4vwxz.jpg.webp 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/640xn/p0m4vwxz.jpg.webp 640w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/800xn/p0m4vwxz.jpg.webp 800w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1024xn/p0m4vwxz.jpg.webp 1024w, Images</span></div><figcaption class="sc-536eff7b-0 jFVvLh">Stone markers along the route show the distance to Nidaros Cathedral, the pilgrimage's endpoint in Trondheim (Credit: Getty Images)</figcaption></figure><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">"Walking in Norway, where there are large variations in nature and weather, makes it more demanding than walking through [Southern] Europe," she said. "The biggest challenge was rainy weather and slippery rocks, differences in altitude and rough terrain. [Elsewhere] in Europe, pilgrims meet in cafes and pubs; churches are open. In Norway, you must carry your food, and many churches are locked. Yet there are compensations: silence, birdsong, rain, fresh air and a sense of being part of the landscape rather than moving through it."</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ"><b class="sc-d16436d-0 kPzeuB" id="more-like-this:">More like this:</b></p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">• <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.bbc.com/travel/article/20201111-a-new-love-for-medieval-style-travel" target="_self">A new love for medieval-style travel</a><a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.bbc.com/travel/article/20241231-travel-in-2025-longer-trips-to-fewer-places" target="_self"></a></p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ"><a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="" target="_blank"></a>• <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.bbc.com/travel/article/20250723-what-santiagos-many-camino-pilgrims-often-miss" target="_self">What Santiago's many 'Camino' pilgrims often miss</a><a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.bbc.com/travel/article/20250102-the-new-travel-retreats-addressing-depression-and-grief" target="_self"></a></p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ"><a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="" target="_blank"></a>• <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.bbc.com/travel/article/20250909-kvikk-lunsj-the-controversial-sweet-that-fuels-norwegians" target="_self">The controversial sweet that fuels Norwegians</a></p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">Accommodation is as varied as the scenery. In Oppdal the <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.oppdalturisthotell.com/" target="_blank">Tourist Hotel</a> provides a comfortable base with hearty breakfasts. A few days further on, the elegant <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.lokkenverk.no/orkla-gjestebolig?utm" target="_blank">Orkla Gjestebolig</a> – once the guest house of a copper mine owner – offers art-filled rooms near the <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://oi.no/en" target="_blank">Orkla Industrial Museum</a>. Mostly, though, pilgrim beds are humbler: converted barns with bunks where animals once slept and simple <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.pilegrimsleden.no/en/overnattingssteder" target="_blank">farmhouses</a> with painted wooden furniture.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">"The Nordic trails are not as developed as the Camino: there are fewer accommodations, and the infrastructure is still in its infancy," Kraan admits. "There are no places to sleep every few kilometres and the standard varies – from hotel to B&B to a simple cabin in someone's backyard. If you don't pre-book in the main season, you might find yourself without a bed. But you can always set up your tent in the wild, thanks to <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.visitnorway.com/plan-your-trip/travel-tips-a-z/right-of-access/" target="_blank"><i class="sc-d16436d-0 gbdkAi" id="allemannsretten">allemannsretten</i></a>, the Nordic 'everyman's right'."</p></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 emRbmv" data-component="advertisement-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 gmBvdA"><div class="sc-1b734f04-1 hBNPuc" data-component="ad-slot" data-testid="ad-unit"><div class="dotcom-ad" data-testid="dotcom-mid_5" id="dotcom-mid_5"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 bwCwRh" data-component="layout-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 iFXyJX"><div class="sc-85f9acf9-0 kySSTS"><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">Three days in, I reached the Orkla, a crystal-clear river famed for salmon. Fish features heavily on menus: salmon, mussels and <i class="sc-d16436d-0 gbdkAi" id="bakt-klippfisk">bakt klippfisk</i> (baked salt cod), alongside pilgrim staples such as lamb stew. Most distinctive of all is <i class="sc-d16436d-0 gbdkAi" id="rømmegrøt">rømmegrøt</i>, a sour-cream porridge with butter, flour and salt — heavy but moreish, perfect fuel for long days. When the path dips into forest, the feast continues: blueberries and cranberries by the handful, or with luck, rare and aptly named cloudberries.</p><figure class="sc-bc40c3a0-0 cEiEXq"><div class="sc-5340b511-1 iLpiHp" data-testid="image"><img aria-label="image unavailable" class="sc-5340b511-0 hagXkB hide-when-no-script" src="https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20250919-090805-05e5ba0164-web-2.30.1-2/grey-placeholder.png"/><img alt="Getty Images Nidaros Cathedral, built on the burial site of St Olav, has been a pilgrimage destination for nearly a millennium (Credit: Getty Images)" class="sc-5340b511-0 bGQwLJ" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 1280px) 50vw, (min-width: 1008px) 66vw, 96vw" src="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0m4vwty.jpg.webp" srcset="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/160xn/p0m4vwty.jpg.webp 160w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/240xn/p0m4vwty.jpg.webp 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/320xn/p0m4vwty.jpg.webp 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/480xn/p0m4vwty.jpg.webp 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/640xn/p0m4vwty.jpg.webp 640w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/800xn/p0m4vwty.jpg.webp 800w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1024xn/p0m4vwty.jpg.webp 1024w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1376xn/p0m4vwty.jpg.webp 1376w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/1920xn/p0m4vwty.jpg.webp 1920w"/><span class="sc-5340b511-2 lha-dta">Getty Images</span></div><figcaption class="sc-536eff7b-0 jFVvLh">Nidaros Cathedral, built on the burial site of St Olav, has been a pilgrimage destination for nearly a millennium (Credit: Getty Images)</figcaption></figure><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">The final days bring the landscape down from high forest to fields of corn and barley. Joggers and roller skaters replace sheep and clapboard houses with fish-scale tiles signal that Trondheim is close. Then, suddenly, the spire of <a class="sc-f9178328-0 jZoZnB" href="https://www.nidarosdomen.no/en/attractions/nidarosdomen" target="_blank">Nidaros Cathedral</a> pierces the skyline – a brooding masterpiece of soapstone with intricate carvings and a great rose window glowing crimson in the late afternoon sun.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">It is an arrival very different from Santiago. There are no queues in the beating sun, no saintly relics to see. Instead, a small, almost unnoticed altar near the wall marks Olav's resting place, scattered with rose petals and pilgrim stones.</p><p class="sc-9a00e533-0 bJoRPJ">Spain's Camino remains iconic, but the heat brought by climate change has made it increasingly challenging. In Norway, on paths once trodden by Vikings and saints, it is still possible to walk with climate, culture and conscience: across windswept landscapes, through traditional Nordic towns and beneath endless skies.</p></div></div></div></div><div class="sc-4b3f2fb3-0 emRbmv" data-component="advertisement-block"><div class="sc-7bf50839-0 cwrLET"><div class="sc-c387a658-0 gmBvdA"><div These are painted on marker posts, rocks and wooden pendants hung from trees.","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"The Gudbrandsdalen path remains the most popular, running 643km from Oslo to Trondheim through farmland, forests, fjords and the open expanses of the Dovre mountains. The full route takes about a month, but shorter sections are easily walked. I opted for the final stretch between Oppdal and Trondheim, covering around 150km over a week. Heading north, the foothills of the Dovre rose to one side, fertile farmland where sheep and reindeer grazed stretched on the other. Tarred timber farm buildings, sun-darkened to a mottled sheen, lined the way.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"The Gudbrandsdalen path remains the most popular, running 643km from Oslo to Trondheim through farmland, forests, fjords and the open expanses of the Dovre mountains.
